Tricia,

I've been looking at the gui test tools as well, and though I've only
looked at one so far -- there were some bugs in the jfcUnit that I'm
going to submit today.  It seems some binary objects have been checked
in as text -- so GIF's are damaged in the documentation, and the
powerpoint tutorial is unreadable.  I'm excited about using these
tools for unit testing the gui elements of my project -- so I'm
interested in the results of your own investigations.

     Harold Shinsato

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Timothy Wall <twall@o...> wrote:
> Do you want to functional/acceptance-test your application, test the 
> GUI, or test your application through your GUI (if the latter, I doubt 
> too many people will want to help you down that path)?
> 
> The toolkits you mentioned are all free, so why don't you invest a 
> little time and determine which works best for you?
> 
> On Feb 2, 2004, at 11:05 AM, Patricia Watt wrote:
> 
> > Hi,
> >
> > I've been asked to find a capture/playback GUI testing tool to use 
> > initially on one of our products that is a stand-alone workbench type 
> > application that does a lot of database operations and has a
canvas to 
> > allow users to add and manipulate data.  Ideally we'd be able to run 
> > the tests as JUnit tests and initiate them from our Ant build files.  
> > Unfortunately no standard JUnit tests were written for the
application 
> > yet.
> >
> > I've been checking out the frameworks/modules listed on junit.org 
> > under Extensions/GUI Tools (Jacareto, Abbot, Marathon, etc.).
> >
> > I'm wondering if people have any experience with these tools (or any 
> > others) and if they can recommend one for the type of application
that 
> > we'll be testing.
> >
> > Thanks in advance for any help.
> > Tricia Watt
